Company: Homegoods, Inc., a division of TJX Corporation
Description: back pay award in unfair labor practices case
Info Source: Extracted from an NLRB dataset covering 1999-2011 downloaded at https://catalog.data.gov/dataset/nlrb-cats-final-c-case-data-bulk-19990101-20110930-in-xml

Description: Fourteen companies agreed to pay a total of $1,055,000 to settle allegations that they knowingly failed to report to the CPSC immediately, as required by federal law, that children's hooded sweatshirts or jackets they sold had drawstrings at the hood and/or neck and thus posed a strangulation hazard.
Info Source: https://www.cpsc.gov/Newsroom/News-Releases/2009/Fourteen-Firms-Agree-to-Pay-More-than-1-Million-in-Civil-Penalties-for-Failing-to-Report-Drawstrings-in-Childrens-Outerwear

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: After a massive breach jeopardized the personal information of 50 million consumers, TJX--the parent company of TJ Maxx, Marshall's, HomeGoods, and A.J. Wright--reached a settlement of multistate litigation under which it would bolster the security of its databases and pay $9.75 million.
Info Source: https://www.oag.ca.gov/news/press-releases/brown-forces-parent-company-tj-maxx-and-marshalls-block-credit-card-hackers

Description: The TJX Companies, Inc. agreed to pay $2,777,500 in settlement of allegations by 35 California District Attorneys and two City Attorneys that its stores violated state laws concerning the handling and disposal of hazardous waste with products they used and sold.
